This token could be traded for screen time or for money.  

The results were incredible.  

Overnight, screen time went down 90 percent.  

Reading went up by the same amount.  

The overall effort to police the system went way down.  

Nonessential activity dramatically decreased.  

Essential activity dramatically increased.  

Once a small amount of initial effort was invested, it worked without friction.  

We can all create systems like this at home and at work.  

The key is to start small, encourage progress, and celebrate small wins.  

Here are a few techniques.  

FOCUS ON MINIMAL VIABLE PROGRESS  

A popular idea in Silicon Valley is “Done is better than perfect.”  

This sentiment is not that we should produce rubbish.  

The idea is not to waste time on nonessentials.  

Just get the thing done.  

In entrepreneurial circles, this idea is expressed as a “minimal viable product.”  

The idea is, “What is the simplest possible product that will be useful?”  

Similarly, we can adopt a method of “minimal viable progress.”  

We can ask ourselves, “What is the smallest amount of progress that will be useful?”  

I used this practice in writing this book.  

For example, when I was still in the exploratory mode, I would share a short idea.  

This was my minimal viable product on Twitter.  

If it resonated with people, I would write a blog piece.  

I published it on Harvard Business Review.  

Through this iterative process, I required very little effort.  

I was able to find connections between my thoughts and others' lives.  

It is the process Pixar uses on their movies.  

Instead of starting with a script, they start with storyboards.  

These are described as the comic book version of a movie.  

They try ideas out and see what works.  

They do this in small cycles hundreds of times.  

Then they put out a movie to small groups for feedback.  

This allows them to learn quickly with little effort.

**PAGE SUMMARY:** Investing small initial efforts in creating systems can lead to significant reductions in nonessential activities and increases in essential activities.
